column4: 👋 it looks like the jar file is missed in the latest release, v9.2.1, can you please verify on your end? Thanks!

column3: infra: remove cache from drone execution
column4: ~~"Fixes" (really allows us to bypass) failure noted at: https://cloud.drone.io/checkstyle/checkstyle/11222/4/2~~  ~~I am guessing that this is the same issue mentioned by @romani regarding dropbox last week in discord:~~  ``` Dropbox. Hi Roman, This email is an automated notification from Dropbox letting you know that your Public links have been temporarily suspended for generating excessive traffic.  ``` The file we are actually downloading now:  ``` ➜  checkstyle git:(fix-infra-2) ✗ curl -o .ci-temp/cache.tar -SsL \     https://www.dropbox.com/s/"sh1g8o4h16p4n""x6"/cache.tar\?dl\=0  ➜  checkstyle git:(fix-infra-2) cat .ci-temp/cache.tar     Dropbox - 404                          Error (404)                 We can't find the page you're looking for.                                      Here are a few links that may be helpful:                                              Home                         Help center                         Sign in                         Get a free account                         Dropbox Plus                         Dropbox Business                                                          ```  ------------------  Summary: dropbox failure preventing us from downloading maven cache helped us to realize that dealing with storing cache elsewhere wasn't really saving us any time in CI. So, we removed the cache restoration completely.

column3: Remove Experimental from XPath Filter
column4: XPath filters have been around since 8.3 in late 2017. We should remove the "experimental" part from them as they have been a normal part for a while.  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/search?q=experimental

column3: Doc: improve grammar in writingchecks.xml
column4: While reading through this document to get started on more substantial contributions, I decided to attempt to fix some grammatical errors present in the document. The content of the text was very helpful, so big thanks there to the writers!

column3: Adding CheckForVariable function to util.sh
column4: Whenever we add a token or key, it is important to check if it exists before we run the shell script.  Currently, I am using this function in the release project but as we use a lot of tokens in different shell scripts, we need to make a general function in util.sh so that we can call this function and remove repetition of creating this function.  Function:  ``` checkForVariable() {     if [[ "$(declare -p "$1")" =~ ^declare\ -x ]]; then        echo "Error: Define $1 environment variable"        exit 1     fi } ```  Usage: `checkForVariable "TOKEN_NAME"`

column3: NPE in gui.MainFrameModel#getLastDirectory
column4: When the GUI invoked with a file, i.e.  ```bash java -cp ...  com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.gui.Main TestClass.java ```  The filed `currentFile` will be set to a file without a parent path.  Subsequently, clicking on "Open File" button fails with NPE in `gui.MainFrameModel#getLastDirectory`

column3: minor: removes complicated uses of test tier that are not needed
column4: Went through the test tier to see why certain methods are still protected and not final. Found some instances were the methods were used in complex ways that weren't needed. Like manually creating the Checker when the verify method will do this for us, etc...

column3: Automate twitter posts to use single shell command
column4: we need to do https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/wiki/How-to-make-a-release#announcements automatically.  we have release notes builder - https://github.com/checkstyle/contribution/tree/master/releasenotes-builder it has ability to do posts in twitter.   TODO: make script in checkstyle/checkstyle repo in folder ".ci", with name `tweet-releasenotes.sh `. script should clone repo to `.ci-temp`  checkout to that tag, build release notes, and do tweet.    Generation of token: https://developer.twitter.com/en/docs/twitter-api/getting-started/getting-access-to-the-twitter-api for our project it is: https://developer.twitter.com/en/portal/projects/1538674835525513216/apps/24628121/keys  Please click on the  DEVELOPER APP -> APP SETTING and give read-write access  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/812984/175821999-c37cd7d1-2278-4ff9-ad07-22eb685bebf2.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/812984/175822343-e495eea7-94ee-4f91-9199-95bf1f557945.png)  **ATTENTION**:  next step should be done only after RW permission are granted. , then  ![FSDF](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71710042/174505756-b9594c2a-e025-42e6-ad7c-edffea590d96.png)  Now click on generate ACCESS TOKEN and SECRET, There you will find Token and Secret Token

column3: Automate update of releasenotes.xml by content for new release

column3: Update GitHub Action for bump-license-year.sh
column4: We have to update the GitHub workflow to bump the license year on the first day of the year.

column3: LineLength gets triggered on multi-line strings for Google Checks
column4: We have a sample of CSV input that we used for documenting REST APIs via OpenAPI, using the shiny new Java 17 multi-line strings (instead of the ugly multi-line manual strings we had before)  ```   static final String LOCATION_CSV_SAMPLE =       """           locationId,label,regionId,regionLabel,vendorId,vendorLabel,address,address2,city,stateProvinceCode,zipCode,countryCode,latitude,longitude           ST001,Station 001,ZONE1,Zone 1,CP1,Competitor 1,123 Street,Unit 2,Houston,TX,77033,US,29.761496813335178,-95.53049214204984           ST002,Station 002,ZONE2,,CP2,,668 Street,Unit 23,San Jose,CA,95191,US,37.35102477242508,-121.9209934020318           """; ```  the LineLength check gets triggerd on this and blocks us from using the benefits of multi-line strings like this.  I think this check should be more flexible and recognize that multi-line strings like this could be used for documentation, etc. and not get triggered.   Otherwise it may nullify one of the greatest benefits of the new multi-line Java 17 strings.

column3: Add 'since' property to '@Deprecated' annotation
column4: We are going to make a major version increase, so it is time to drop some deprecated methods.  - [x] AbstractCheck#getFileContents #11166 - [x] Configuration#getAttribute #10164 - [x] Configuration#getAttributeNames #10164 - [x] DefaultConfiguration#addAttribute #10164 - [x] DetailAST#branchContains #5234 - [x] DetailAST#getNumberOfChildren #7512  https://sonarcloud.io/project/issues?id=org.checkstyle%3Acheckstyle&resolved=false&severities=MAJOR  https://www.baeldung.com/java-deprecated#optional-attributes   /DefaultConfiguration.java https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blame/master/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/DefaultConfiguration.java#L143 since 8.45, forRemoval=true  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blame/master/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/api/AbstractCheck.java#L195 since 9.3  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blame/master/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/api/Configuration.java#L39 since 8.45, forRemoval=true  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blame/master/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/api/DetailAST.java#L101 since 8.43 forRemoval=true  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blame/master/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/api/DetailAST.java#L141 since 8.30, forRemoval=true  it might be good time to remove all that deprecated methods (except for getFileContent as we still use it #10976  so fix could be simply removal of such methods :) But better to make special issue for this to list it in release notes. update annotation better to be done sooner .... as it is quick fix and merge, removal of methods might be not simple and affect other projects and execution on them.  _Originally posted by @romani in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/9146#issuecomment-1030709274_

column3: Surviving mutations for conditions reducing time complexity
column4: Two mutation cases to discuss, these conditions are present to reduce the time complexity.  1. ```                                                                              PackageObjectFactory.java                                                    com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.PackageObjectFactory                     createModule                                                           org.pitest.mutationtest.engine.gregor.mutators.RemoveConditionalMutator_EQUAL_IF   removed conditional - replaced equality check with true                    if (thirdPartyNameToFullModuleNames == null) {                                                                                                                      ``` Complete relevant code https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/678c547af6de156c604595fe42ffdd0cb05c0023/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/PackageObjectFactory.java#L189-L193  This null check is present to reduce the time complexity, the method `generateThirdPartyNameToFullModuleName(..)` uses `moduleClassLoader` (final instance field) and `packages` (another final instance field) so even if  `thirdPartyNameToFullModuleNames` is recalculated again and again the result will be the same. The only way it can change is if you access the internal fields, for eg - `packages` using reflections and add an element to the set. But in the current code those fields are not modified.   2. ```                                                                              PackageObjectFactory.java                                                    com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.PackageObjectFactory                     createModule                                                           org.pitest.mutationtest.engine.gregor.mutators.RemoveConditionalMutator_EQUAL_IF   removed conditional - replaced equality check with true                    if (!name.contains(PACKAGE_SEPARATOR)) {                                                                                                                            ```  Complete relevant code https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/678c547af6de156c604595fe42ffdd0cb05c0023/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/PackageObjectFactory.java#L186-L196  The mutation is replacing the condition with true, if there is some name with `PACKAGE_SEPARATOR` that enters this branch, then it is guaranteed that it will still remain null. `createFromStandardCheckSet(..)` the standard check set does not contain any module which has `PACKAGE_SEPARATOR` in its short name. `generateThirdPartyNameToFullModuleName(..)` implementation guarantees it that there are no short names which contain `PACKAGE_SEPARATOR` as it uses `Class#getSimpleName()` to get the short name. This condition is only present to reduce the time complexity.

column3: Report unused dependencies in CI
column4: Thought about at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11064 and then identified at https://www.baeldung.com/maven-unused-dependencies ,  We need a way to identify unused dependencies and be alerted that they should be removed.  We should add `mvn dependency:analyze` to our CI to report unused dependencies.  How to make the command fail the build: https://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-dependency-plugin/examples/failing-the-build-on-dependency-analysis-warnings.html  This may not get much usage, but I think it would be good to make sure we don't have to worry about it anymore too.

column3: Pitest: Kill all surviving mutations
column4: This will be main tracker issue for killing surviving mutations before we begin work in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/11719  Now that we have diff report generation as github action, let's modify the procedure from  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/7797#issue-577522554 a bit to speed this up:  1. Disable all CI first as separate commit(See example at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11721). This will help to not waste credits. 2. Pick one single surviving mutation from pitest.sh. 3. Send PR with a single hardcoded mutation only. 4. Generate diff report with hardcoded mutation. 5. Share link to initial commit with hardcoded mutation and initial diff report in PR description. This is in lieu of separate branch/ etc. in previous issue at #7797.   HARDCODED MUTATION WILL NOT BE IN FINAL PR.  We will have one of three outcomes for each mutation (in order of preference): 1. Find a case that kills the mutation via diff report, add new test in existing PR 2. Safely (no regressions) modify code to be covered, in existing PR 3. Safely (no regressions) remove code to be covered, in existing PR  Case (2) and (3) required a detailed analysis and discussion in issue before making any changes.  -----------------------------------  **We will not be pursuing surviving mutations in IndentationCheck or gui package .**

column3: Fatal Errors in Logs after Upgrade from 10.1 to 10.2
column4: This report is not about a check and its pure `jar` execution in particular, but I assume some form of regression.  Running the following command  ```bash mvn --activate-profiles checkstyle checkstyle:check ```  with the maven profile  ```xml      checkstyle                                                                  org.apache.maven.plugins                     maven-checkstyle-plugin                     3.1.2                                               .checkstyle/config.xml                         true                                                                                                 com.puppycrawl.tools                             checkstyle                             10.2                                                                                            ```  will print message multiple times `[Fatal Error] control.xml:1:1: Content is not allowed in prolog.`  ``` [INFO] --- maven-checkstyle-plugin:3.1.2:check (default-cli) @ my.project --- [Fatal Error] control.xml:1:1: Content is not allowed in prolog. [Fatal Error] control.xml:1:1: Content is not allowed in prolog. [Fatal Error] control.xml:1:1: Content is not allowed in prolog. [Fatal Error] control.xml:1:1: Content is not allowed in prolog. [INFO] You have 0 Checkstyle violations. ```  using the version `10.1` as in  ```xml      checkstyle                                                                  org.apache.maven.plugins Though it triggers for some reason on basically empty projects  ```bash ls ./my.project pom.xml ```  I also checked the commits between 10.1 and 10.2, but on the first glimpse did not find a specific offender  https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/compare/checkstyle-10.1...checkstyle-10.2

column3: Issue #11370: use naive implementation for isOfType
column4: This PR proposed to use a naive implementation for `TokenUtil.isOfType`, as discussed in #11370. This yields a significant speedup of Checkstyle run-time.

column3: Update Tests to use new 'verifyXxxxxx' method or 'execute' that use inlined config in Input files
column4: this is phase 2 of updates at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10390#issuecomment-1065935409 please see [related commit](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/commit/e77a62f2bffc200f9eb5b6702e6d3d3fc50d8ce8)  to see how to update code and remove suppression line.  Test need to be updated: - [x] AllSinglelineCommentsTest  - [x] SuppressionCommentFilterTest - [ ] EmptyLineSeparatorCheckTest - [ ] SuppressWarningsHolderTest - [ ] ImportControlCheckTest - [x] ImportOrderCheckTest - [x] SuppressWithNearbyCommentFilterTest - [x] CommentsIndentationCheckTest - [ ] SuppressionFilterTest - [ ] WriteTagCheckTest - [ ] AbstractJavadocCheckTest   suppression that was added at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11441 should be reemoved.  each Test should be updated in separate PR to ease review.  all usages of `verify` method should be changed to verifyWithInlineConfigParser or similar method that use Inlined to Input file configs. OR update to use `execute` method when test expect exception during execution and checking of violation is not required.   There are several test methods that create internal Check just to cover code by test and no verification of Java code, so `execute` method should be used instead `verify`.

column3: minor: remove testLocaleIsSupported tests
column4: These tests are useless. If the **user.language** property is set to anything else but English, 200+ tests will fail. So we need a dedicated test suite to validate all supported languages.

column3: minor: Set default locale for unit test execution to "en"
column4: There are a few unit tests that rely on the default locale language being set to english because they make assertions about localized messages. On systems where the default locale language is not "en", these tests fail.  This change sets the default language for test execution to "en" as surefire argument.  Other than that, I couldn't help but fixing some assertions in `DefaultLoggerTest` to improve the failure messages.

column3: EmptyLineSeparator does not catch missing line separator before field declaration
column4: The documentation of EmptyLineSeparator says "Checks for empty line separators before package, all import declarations, **fields**, constructors, methods, nested classes, static initializers and instance initializers." In particular, it doesn't work for fields, see example below. Since a field is also known as an instance variable, I expect the VARIABLE_DEF to catch it, but it doesn't.  I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_whitespace.html#EmptyLineSeparator I have downloaded the latest checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the cli and showed it below, as cli describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ javac Test.java   peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ cat config.xml     	 		 	   peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ cat Test.java  class Test { 	int i = 0; // Checkstyle doesn't catch missing line break before this line. Should be caught by VARIABLE_DEF? 	Test() { // Checkstyle DOES catch missing line break before this line. Caught by CTOR_DEF. 	} }  peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US"  peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.3-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/peter/Downloads/checkstyle/Test.java:3:9: 'CTOR_DEF' should be separated from previous line. [EmptyLineSeparator] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ```  --- **Expected: Checkstyle reports 2 violations, one for CTOR_DEF and one for VARIABLE_DEF.** **Actual: Checkstyle reports 1 violation, for CTOR_DEF.** ---  To give an idea of the code style I want to enforce:  ```java class AlwaysNewlineAfterClassDeclaration {      int field = 0; // Newline before is required. }  class AlsoInAnymousInnerClasses {      Supplier supplier = new Supplier() {          public String get() { // Newline before is required.         }     } } // Newline before is prohibited.  class UnlessEmpty { } // Newline before is prohibited. ```  So I want to be able to configure the following violations:  ```java class AlwaysNewlineAfterClassDeclaration {     int field = 0; // Violation. }  class AlsoInAnymousInnerClasses {      Supplier supplier = new Supplier() {         public String get() { // Violation.         }     }  } // Violation, out of scope of this issue.  class UnlessEmpty {  } // Violation, out of scope of this issue. ```

column3: EmptyStatement does not catch all empty statements
column4: The Coding/EmptyStatement module does not catch all empty statements that I expect it to. It _does_ catch the one(s) it describes in the example it its own documentation, but it does not catch some others. In the example below, I've put 3 empty statements, and it catches only 1 of them. Depending on your viewpoint, this is either a bug or an improvement request of an existing feature. I lean towards bug because IntelliJ _does_ flag all 3 occurrences correctly.  I have read check documentation: https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_coding.html#EmptyStatement I have downloaded the latest Checkstyle from: https://checkstyle.org/cmdline.html#Download_and_Run I have executed the CLI and showed it below, as CLI describes the problem better than 1,000 words  ```bash peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ javac Test.java  peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ cat config.xml     	 		 	   peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ cat Test.java  class Test {  	; // Checkstyle should flag this but doesn't. 	int i = 0;; // This too. IntelliJ detects it by the way...  	void test() { 		int i = 5; 		if (i < 3); // This DOES get flagged by Checkstyle. 			i++; 	} }  peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ RUN_LOCALE="-Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US" peter@pangolin:~/Downloads/checkstyle$ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.3-all.jar -c config.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/peter/Downloads/checkstyle/Test.java:8:27: Empty statement. [EmptyStatement] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors. ```  ---  **Expected:** Checkstyle catches all 3 violations and ends with "Checkstyle ends with 3 errors." and exit code 3. **Actual:** Checkstyle catches 1 violation and ends with "Checkstyle ends with 1 errors." and exit code 1. ---

column3: Disable IDEA Inspection for  `AnnotationClass`
column4: The `AnnotationClass` inspection is a "Java Language Level" issue, which pertains to Java versions less than 1.5 (Java 5). Since we only support jdk/jre >= 11, this inspection is not relevant to the project. Sadly, the IDEA inspections website has no information about this inspection, but from the "Inspections" view in Intellij:   `Reports annotation interfaces. Such interfaces are not supported in Java 1.4 and earlier JVM. `   ~~The `'assert' statement` inspection pertains to Java versions less than 1.3 (Java 3). Since we only support jdk/jre >= 11, this inspection is not relevant to the project. Sadly, the IDEA inspections website also has no information about this inspection, but from the "Inspections" view in Intellij:~~  ~~`Reports assert statements. By default, assert statements are disabled during execution in the production environment. Consider using logger or exceptions instead. The assert statements are not supported in Java 1.3 and earlier JVM. `~~  We can safely remove ~~these two~~ this inspection since we do not support language levels below 11.

column3: inner lambdas right curly idented too much on left to much same ident as wrapper statement
column4: taken from https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/10772/commits/7cd6a8bffdb0a2af57ec67deb888616f3e8f5254#diff-af82a596b896afaece68cf7938ec0b6a7e51de544d79f1918564f599c21f5c76R501  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/812984/155261830-bbed8f34-35d1-4c35-aacc-5e817b518453.png)  might be same same/conflicting with https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/3182  fix to make it more read-able to me is: ``` ✔ ~/java/github/romani/checkstyle [octylFractal/feature/inline-return-tag-javadoc L|✚ 1]  20:20 $ git diff diff --git a/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/SummaryJavadocCheck.java b/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/SummaryJavadocCheck.java index d02ff5d..e5916a8 100644 --- a/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/SummaryJavadocCheck.java +++ b/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/javadoc/SummaryJavadocCheck.java @@ -501,11 +501,12 @@ public class SummaryJavadocCheck extends AbstractJavadocCheck {      private void validateInlineReturnTag(DetailNode ast) {          final Optional inlineTagNode = getInlineTagNode(ast);          // Text is stored in the first DESCRIPTION node's child -        final String inlineReturn = inlineTagNode.flatMap(node -> { -            return Arrays.stream(node.getChildren()) -                    .filter(child -> child.getType() == JavadocTokenTypes.DESCRIPTION) -                    .findFirst(); -        }) +        final String inlineReturn = inlineTagNode.flatMap( +                node -> { +                    return Arrays.stream(node.getChildren()) +                            .filter(child -> child.getType() == JavadocTokenTypes.DESCRIPTION) +                            .findFirst(); +                })              .map(descNode -> descNode.getChildren()[0].getText())              .orElse("");          final String returnVisible = getVisibleContent(inlineReturn); ```

column3: Suppressions to XPath Suppressions
column4: Subset of https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/11604 ,  Clarification is needed here and in the code on what is the relationship between xpath suppressions and normal suppressions. There are a few conflicts in the code base and there is no simple answer on what this would mean if possibly another walker is added.  Resolving this can help clear up the code and possibly make the design simpler and more expandable in the future. Maybe we create a whole new interface to show the parent/child relationship, or maybe we split code apart to show no connection. It could also mean breaking the existing design for something that makes more sense.  For simplicity, lets say Checker is another form of Walker, it does no parsing but loads the files.  ###  Are xpath suppressions a sub-filter of suppressions?  Currently suppressions and xpath suppressions code is in the same file, https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/master/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/filters/SuppressionsLoader.java#L140 .  DTD also says the suppression file supports both xpath and non-xpath, https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/master/src/main/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/suppressions_1_2_xpath_experimental.dtd#L8 .  This makes it seem like there is a parent-child relationship between the 2.  ### Are xpath suppressions a completely different type of suppressions and there is no similarity between them in hierarchy?  We store the filters in completely separate areas, https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/master/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/filters/SuppressionsLoader.java#L116-L121 .  Even if we load them all from a single file, only the specific filter for each will activate each type of suppression. Meaning if we only add `SuppressionXpathFilter` to a config, it will not suppress anything from the non-xpath suppressions. It requires the `SuppressionFilter` to be added for those.  The DTD also shows that not everything from non-xpath is pulled into xpath. We dropped lines and columns in xpath, and xpath has the unique field query.   This makes it seem more like there is no real parent-child relationship besides them both being a form of suppression. I would more closely say that xpath is tree's filter, while non-xpath is checker's filter.  ### 3rd option  Since there is always another option, is there a certain part that of suppressions that should be declared as parent/child and the other parts are actually customization of their respective walkers.  Or....

column3: Specify violation messages in input files.
column4: Single Check might have multiple violations messages, we need to see exact violation message if Check has multiple messages, to be sure that violation of correct type is placed at right line.  Violation messages have not been specified in certain input files, a list of checks in which violation message is not specified in the input file and have more than one violation message key has been specified here- https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/d6bf623e60f337ca2598adfaa0ba8fe3922241b2/src/test/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/bdd/InlineConfigParser.java#L99  To Do-  - Pick a check (single Check Inputs files update in single Pull Request) To allocate Check update for you please make comment in issue "I am on XxxxxCheck" - Find all input files that use that check - Add violation message at the end of the `// violation` comment - Remove the check from the suppression list  Same has been demonstrated at 461cd048bb059ea6948945104682fb99d4e155dc If the violation message contains special regex characters, escape that character. Ignore input files using more than a single check.  Ignore lines with multiple violations, eg- ``` // 2 violations // 2 violations above // 4 violations below ``` and any other violation message of this nature.  List of checks-  - [x] RightCurlyCheck - [x] EqualsAvoidNullCheck - [x] MethodParamPadCheck - [ ] DescendantTokenCheck - [ ] RequireThisCheck - [x] EqualsHashCodeCheck - [ ] JavaNCSSCheck - [x] ReturnCountCheck - [ ] AnnotationUseStyleCheck - [ ] EmptyLineSeparatorCheck - [x] OrderedPropertiesCheck - [ ] AbstractJavadocCheck - [x] DeclarationOrderCheck - [x] MissingOverrideCheck - [x] AbstractClassNameCheck - [x] MethodCountCheck - [ ] PackageDeclarationCheck - [ ] JavadocTypeCheck - [x] LeftCurlyCheck - [ ] RegexpCheck - [x] WhitespaceAfterCheck - [x] MultipleVariableDeclarationsCheck - [x] EmptyForInitializerPadCheck - column3: Tracker for pitest-coding failures
column4: Since we have been seeing random (but regular) failures in `pitest-coding`, I thought it would be a good idea to track exactly which lines are causing pitest to fail. Maintainers, feel free to just add any failures that you notice below (in issue description).  - [x] `EqualsAvoidNullCheck.java.html:            if (field.findFirstToken(TokenTypes.IDENT) != null) {`    https://nick-mancuso.github.io/pit-reports-equal/202203230810/com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding/EqualsAvoidNullCheck.java.html    Negated conditional  - [x] `RequireThisCheck.java.html:            if (returnedVariable) {`    Report at https://nick-mancuso.github.io/pit-reports-requirethis/202203211238/com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding/RequireThisCheck.java.html    Removed  conditional  - [ ] `CheckstyleAntTask.java.html:            if (toFile == null || !useFile) {`    https://pbludov.github.io/pitest-ant-coverage-report/pit-reports/202203270532/com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.ant/CheckstyleAntTask.java.html#org.pitest.mutationtest.report.html.SourceFile@352b92be_720    removed conditional - replaced equality check with true → SURVIVED  Hopefully we can diagnose issue and make `pitest-coding` more stable.

column3: infra: add permissions for site workflow
column4: Similar to https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11014#issue-1073832545, hopefully this fixes site generation issue.  Example of failure: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/actions/runs/1559956127  Failure seems to be related to writing rocket emoji to comment where `Github, generate site` is placed.  Even if this does not fix failure, it is a good idea to update permissions.  From https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11014#issue-1073832545:  > It's still worth taking [this PR] even if you undo the repo settings change; it limits the permissions for this workflow to the minimum required.

column3: New RegexpSinglelineJava property ignoreStrings/ignoreTextBlocks
column4: Similar idea discussed at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/1405  https://checkstyle.org/config_regexp.html#RegexpSinglelineJava  ``` java --version openjdk 17.0.3     2022-04-19 OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 17.0.3+7-Ubuntu-0ubuntu0.22.04.1) OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (build 17.0.3+7-Ubuntu-0ubuntu0.22.04.1, mixed mode, sharing) ```  ```bash /var/tmp $ javac Test.java #[[COMPILATION IS SUCCESSFUL]]  /var/tmp $ cat checkstyle.xml     	 	 		 			 			 			 			 		 	   # attention: tabs characters are used, copy code from edit mode /var/tmp $ cat Test.java public class Test { 	private static String test = """ 		{ 		  "health": { 		    "inited": true, 		    "installed": true, 		    "dbOk": true 		  } 		}""";  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		System.out.println(test); 	} }  /var/tmp $ java -Duser.language=en -Duser.country=US -jar ../checkstyle-10.2-all.jar -c checkstyle.xml Test.java Starting audit... [ERROR] /home/solomax/work/tmp/checkstyle/11653/Test.java:4: Indent must use tab characters [tabs-only] [ERROR] /home/solomax/work/tmp/checkstyle/11653/Test.java:5: Indent must use tab characters [tabs-only] [ERROR] /home/solomax/work/tmp/checkstyle/11653/Test.java:6: Indent must use tab characters [tabs-only] [ERROR] /home/solomax/work/tmp/checkstyle/11653/Test.java:7: Indent must use tab characters [tabs-only] [ERROR] /home/solomax/work/tmp/checkstyle/11653/Test.java:8: Indent must use tab characters [tabs-only] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 5 errors. ```  **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.** Checkstyle should report no issues since all leading spaces inside `text block` are "removed" remaining white-spaces are not code and might follow it's own rules  **Describe the solution you'd like** I would be happy with  - dedicated check for tab-indentation - special option for `RegexpSinglelineJava` to ignore strings/text block   ```bash Starting audit... Audit done. ```

column3: Use Shellcheck to resolve violations code in Shell Script
column4: ShellCheck is an open-source static analysis tool that automatically finds bugs in your shell scripts. (https://github.com/koalaman/shellcheck)  For more information on Code: https://gist.github.com/nicerobot/53cee11ee0abbdc997661e65b348f375#file-_shellcheck-md  `./.ci/*sh` has all the shell scripts files and we have all the disabled violations at the `.shellcheckrc` file. We are currently invoking spellcheck through Terminal (You can download (https://github.com/koalaman/shellcheck#installing) it through apt or similar package managers on local). We have integrated Shellcheck with Travis CI (https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11627)  TO-DO: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/1ef8fdd682e7a3e58df59b6c1eabc3d5829a1e36/.shellcheckrc#L1-L3  - Pick a suppression (single suppression  fix in single Pull Request) To allocate a suppression update for you please make comment in the issue "I am on "SCxxxxSuppression" - Remove Your Selected Suppression from the `.shellcheckrc` file. - Run shellcheck through Terminal and See Errors - Fix the Errors and make a PR.   LIST OF SUPPRESSIONS:  - [x] SC2086 # (info): Double quote to prevent globbing and word splitting. - [ ] SC2006 # (style): Use $(...) notation instead of legacy backticks .... - [ ] SC2046 # (warning): Quote this to prevent word splitting. - [ ] SC2207 # (warning): Prefer mapfile or read -a to split command output. - [ ] SC2002 # (style): Useless cat. Consider 'cmd < file | ..' or 'cmd file | ..' instead. - [ ] SC2061 # (warning): Quote the parameter to -name so the shell won't interpret it. - [ ] SC2035 # (info): Use ./glob or -- glob so names with dashes won't become options. - [x] SC2236 # (style): Use -n instead of ! -z. - [ ] SC2016 # (info): Expressions don't expand in single quotes, use double quotes for that. - [ ] SC2185 # (info): Some finds don't have a default path. Specify '.' explicitly. - [ ] SC2155 # (warning): Declare and assign separately to avoid masking return values. - [ ] SC2071 # (error): > is for string comparisons. Use -gt instead. - [ ] SC2034 # (warning): RUN_JOB appears unused. Verify use (or export if used externally). - [ ] SC2216 # (warning): Piping to 'true', a command that doesn't read stdin. - [ ] SC2013 # (info): To read lines rather than words, pipe/redirect to a 'while read' loop. - [x] SC2206 # (warning): Quote to prevent word splitting/globbing. - [ ] SC2143 # (style): Use grep -q instead of comparing output with [ -n .. ]. - [ ] SC2004 # (style): $/${} is unnecessary on arithmetic variables. - [ ] SC2087 # (warning): Quote 'EOF' to make here document expansions happen on the server-side. - [ ] SC2102 # (info): Ranges can only match single chars (mentioned due to duplicates). - [ ] SC2242 # (error): Can only exit with status 0-255. - [ ] SC2115 # (warning): Use "${var:?}" to ensure this never expands to /* . - [ ] SC2128 # (warning): Expanding an array without an index only gives the first element. - [ ] SC2063 # (warning): Grep uses regex, but this looks like a glob. - [ ] SC2126 # (style): Consider using grep -c instead of grep|wc -l. - [ ] SC2088 # (warning): Tilde does not expand in quotes. Use $HOME. - [ ] SC2005 # (style): Useless echo? Instead of 'echo $(cmd)', just use 'cmd'. - [ ] SC2015 # (info): Note that A && B || C is not if-then-else. C may run when A is true. - [ ] SC2026 # (info): This word is outside of quotes. - [x] SC2269 # (info): This variable is assigned to itself, so the assignment does nothing. - [ ] SC2230: which is non-standard. Use builtin 'command -v' instead. - [ ] SC2153: Possible Misspelling: MYVARIABLE may not be assigned, but MY_VARIABLE is. - [ ] SC1004: This backslash+linefeed is literal. Break outside single quotes if you want to break the line.  Example of expected update with removal of suppression: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/commit/5ea26d6a8f8338bed3dba9de4b64e7af22879f70

column3: Pitest: Activate "ALL" mutator group
column4: See https://pitest.org/quickstart/mutators/  **As an initial step, we will generate an initial report with all mutators for each profile and share via github.io in a comment below. This will help us to understand scope of work before we begin.**  In all profiles, we will activate the "ALL" group of mutators, using the following procedure:  1. Pick one profile from checklist below 2. Amend mutators to include the "ALL" group 3. Create suppressions necessary to achieve green state in CI 4. Add suppressions to a main tracker issue (TODO)   ---------------------------  Some notes:  - Mutator [NON_VOID_METHOD_CALLS](http://pitest.org/quickstart/mutators/#NON_VOID_METHOD_CALLS) is considered unstable for certain types like Objects where NullPointerExceptions are likely - We are excluding `InlineConstantMutator` for all profiles with link to comment from https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11873#discussion_r920652226  -------------------------  - [x] pitest-misc - [x] pitest-annotation - [x] pitest-blocks - [x] pitest-coding-1 - [x] pitest-coding-2 - [x] pitest-coding-require-this-check - [x] pitest-design - [x] pitest-header - [x] pitest-imports - [x] pitest-indentation - [x] pitest-javadoc - [x] pitest-metrics - [x] pitest-modifier - [x] pitest-naming - [x] pitest-regexp - [x] pitest-sizes - [x] pitest-whitespace - [x] pitest-ant - [x] pitest-packagenamesloader - [x] pitest-common - [x] pitest-common-2 - [x] pitest-main - [x] pitest-tree-walker - [x] pitest-api - [x] pitest-filters - [x] pitest-utils - [x] pitest-gui - [x] pitest-xpath - [x] pitest-java-ast-visitor  ------------------------------ **We will not be pursuing surviving mutations in IndentationCheck or gui package .**

column3: Convert regressions that use maven-checkstyle-plugin to CLI based
column4: See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MCHECKSTYLE-346 . We need to deprecate all usage of maven-checkstyle-plugin so we can start implementing backward breaking changes.  A lot of regressions use maven-checkstyle-plugin to run checkstyle on the projects and will have to be converted to using the raw CLI. Example is anything using `checkstyle:check` via a maven command. https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/search?l=Shell&q=%22checkstyle%3Acheck%22  This may be difficult for some projects as they use custom dependencies. We may have to start discussions with the project owners on how we can best do this and disable them until we can get things worked out.

column3: Adding More Labels to the Issue
column4: Right now, checkstyle generally uses a `miscellaneous` label for the issues which are general.  Proposal: We should introduce more `labels` for the issues so that it can make new contributors easy to find issues. By checking for `approved` and `miscellaneous`, it is sometimes overwhelming.   We can introduce labels like:  - `Shell` ( for shell/bash script issues) - `Pitest` (For Pitest related issues) - Instead of GSoC First Issues, We can use `Good First Issues`  and many more.  The main aim of this issue is to focus on `specialization` instead of `generalization` to help contributors find it easy to contribute.   @romani @rnveach @nick-mancuso @pbludov @strkkk @Vyom-Yadav, Would you please share your opinion?

column3: satelite projects should use latest  checkstyle as soon at is appears in maven repo
column4: Right now we do bump a version in few projects https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/wiki/How-to-make-a-release#update-for-released-version-reference right after release.  Lets find way to define in pom.xml latest snapshot version of most recent version. And latest released version when we define dependencies. To let us skip such updates at all.  CI of such projects should be able to get latest version from https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/maven-metadata.xml  and run projects with such version.  We can have in all such repos, GitHub action that runs ones a day check https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/maven-metadata.xml , put such values in required files and send PRs with changes (PR is required as we need notice is any problems happens if we introduce breaking changes)   Abandoned approach: it should be 2 separate scripts for each group that I (later it will be done by CI) should be able to execute from local.  script should clone repository(ies), update sources and push changes back to github,clean up temp clones.  scripts should be at `.ci` folder. all clones should be done to `.ci-temp` folder.  Updates of xml by shell https://github.com/sevntu-checkstyle/sevntu.checkstyle/blob/master/pom-version-bump.sh That we use in release of sevntu project https://github.com/sevntu-checkstyle/sevntu.checkstyle/wiki/How-to-release-sevntu.checkstyle

column3: Issue #7064: Add influenceFormat property to SuppressWithPlainTextCommentFilter
column4: Resolves #7064 ## Changes * Adds `influenceFormat` property along with `commentFormat` * Adds 3 tests to cover new property * Updates all other tests with a lot more examples covering the new change * Updates all other tests' inline configurations to include the new property * Updates documentation about the new property(I will provide screenshots of the website once the problem below is discussed)     * Examples of how this prop is used in javadoc and site are not added. I didn't add them yet because I think adding a reference to `SuppressWithNearbyCommentFilter`'s examples might be better. In the end it's the same prop doing the exact same thing. No need to repeat it. Let me know what you think.  ---  Diff Regression config: https://gist.githubusercontent.com/stoyanK7/0d95fd3ec8caa5cae9eb597ac8c78b8d/raw/c60fcc04f28f853f530efeceb598e6b5173d4855/config.xml

column3: Issue #6658: Kill surviving mutation in PkgImportControl related to regex
column4: Resolves #6658   **Check Documentation:** https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/config_imports.html#ImportControl  ### Diff Reports:  N/A  ### This mutation falls into the category:  - Logic was analyzed to develop the test case.

column3: Issue #6295: Increase mutation coverage for javadoc profile to 100%
column4: Resolves #6295 Hardcoded mutation tested at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11770  ### Reports with hardcoded mutation (clean, they were generated again in this PR):  - DefaultConfig: https://checkstyle-diff-reports.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/9fcdf03_2022032211/reports/diff/index.html - PublicScope: https://checkstyle-diff-reports.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/9fcdf03_2022043748/reports/diff/index.html  ### This mutation falls in the category:  - Safely (no regressions) remove code to be covered  ### Rationale:  The current method implementation gave the next point of examination, earlier it was giving the next position by skipping all the whitespace and starting from `*` in the Javadoc comment.  In the current implementation, we gradually check each and every point, it won't be a performance hit as the number of iterations will remain the same, earlier we did the extra iterations in `while (column < currentLineLength`, now we will be doing them in the methods that are calling  `getNextPoint(..)`.

column3: Issue #11665: Create a robust method of surviving mutation suppression
column4: Resolves #11665   Only the last commit is under review.  Proofs ->  - [x] [CI task](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/runs/7005315685?check_suite_focus=true) failing from 1 extra mutation in file - [x] [CI task](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/runs/7005314642?check_suite_focus=true) failing from more than 1 extra mutation in file - [x] [CI task](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/runs/7005316210?check_suite_focus=true) failing from 1 missing mutation in file - [x] [CI task](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/runs/7005314199?check_suite_focus=true) failing from more than 1 missing mutation in file - [x] Proof of parsing comments in suppression file, multiple line and single. Comments are present in multiple suppressions files, with no problem whatsoever. - [x] Proof of same mutations from pitest.sh via cli (can just use grep/ sed/ diff). We may have been obfuscating multiple violations previously, we should keep this in mind when considering results.  [Here](https://www.diffchecker.com/ncsTkNgX) is the difference between old pitest suppressions and new pitest suppressions. The topmost mutation `}` is due to https://github.com/hcoles/pitest/issues/688 (See [this](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/11720#issuecomment-1163248051)) and the 6 added mutations were multiple mutations on the same line. Report is good according to me. A mix of `sed`, `awk`, `groovy` was used, report is accurate.   - [x] --list functionality ([CI task](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/runs/7005319100?check_suite_focus=true))

column3: Issue #11442: Check no closed issue references workflow is now triggered on pull requests
column4: Resolves #11442 Tested at - https://github.com/Vyom-Yadav/actions-test/pull/39 https://github.com/Vyom-Yadav/actions-test/pull/40  Direct push to master - https://github.com/Vyom-Yadav/actions-test/runs/5655841079?check_suite_focus=true  Push to PR (not from fork) - https://github.com/Vyom-Yadav/actions-test/runs/5655783382?check_suite_focus=true  Push to PR (from fork) - https://github.com/Vyom-Yadav/actions-test/runs/5655810498?check_suite_focus=true  ---  What this PR does-  1. **Improved reporting:-** A clickable link is now given to the user which redirects it to the line where the closed issue is referenced.  2. **Runs on a PR:-** The job now runs on a PR too. 3. **Issues linked to PR are mentioned:-** If the developer has linked some issue to the PR and that issue is referenced somewhere in the code then a violation will be given out to user. Rationale behind this is that if you [link](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) an issue to a PR then when that PR is merged, then that issue would be automatically closed, linking issue is different than just mentioning it.

column3: Pull #11904: Remove pitest mutation checking HTML model
column4: Remove `pitest-survival-check-html.sh` as new XML model covers are useful cases.  ### One case not covered by the XML model (as it is based on `mutations.xml`):  The new pitest method only examines `mutations.xml` which isn't appropriate to determine lines that are uncovered and are not mutated (due to the absence of some mutator). Such lines can only be taken from the HTML file.  An example of such lines is present over [here](https://vyom-yadav.github.io/DiffReport/pit-blocks-mod-1/index.html) (modified a bit for demonstrating).  Though uncovered lines will result in low line coverage, it is rounded up in certain cases ([example](https://vyom-yadav.github.io/DiffReport/pit-blocks-mod-single-line/index.html)) and the line coverage becomes 100% :( https://github.com/hcoles/pitest/issues/375   Mutations on lines that have no coverage are of type `NO_COVERAGE`, such mutations are **supported** by the XML report checker.  But it shouldn't be a problem as we have jacoco for line coverage and if there are multiple uncovered lines, then pitest line coverage will also drop and it will fail.  ---  The issue for XML report not containing information about uncovered lines is created at https://github.com/hcoles/pitest/issues/1059  ---  In some cases when the number of mutators is limited, some uncovered lines are also mutated and mutants are present in the XML report. In the mock example below, line 277 is uncovered but has a mutation with status `NO_COVERAGE` ![Screenshot from 2022-07-20 10-26-36](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73882557/179900365-2ff41eee-1c98-4991-bd08-03b5ef0e0c47.png) ![Screenshot from 2022-07-20 10-28-53](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73882557/179900507-287aa197-5b70-415d-9bcb-3a20949dc04e.png)  Lines 274, 275, and 276 are uncovered and nothing about them is present in the XML report. See the report [here](https://vyom-yadav.github.io/DiffReport/pit-blocks-mod-1/com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.blocks/EmptyBlockCheck.java.html) (Mock Example)

column3: Issue #11140: Resolve PMB_POSSIBLE_MEMORY_BLOAT issue 1
column4: Related to https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/11140  ``` PMB_POSSIBLE_MEMORY_BLOAT This class defines static fields that are Collections, StringBuffers, or StringBuilders that do not appear to have any way to clear or reduce their size. That is, a collection is defined and has method calls like {add(), append(), offer(), put(), ...} with no method calls to removal methods like {clear(), delete(), pop(), remove(), ...} This means that the collection in question can only ever increase in size, which is a potential cause of memory bloat.  If this collection is a list, set or otherwise of static things (e.g. a List>String> for month names), consider adding all of the elements in a static initializer, which can only be called once:  private static List monthNames = new ArrayList(); static { monthNames.add("January"); monthNames.add("February"); monthNames.add("March"); ... }   ```

column3: 3 tests in EmptyLineSeparatorCheckTest cannot be updated to use verifyWithInlineConfigParser() due to coverage issues
column4: Related to #11446  ## The tests * `testPrePreviousLineEmptiness()` https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5444844c338dfe2b9a3543721af62cc40113ecee/src/test/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/EmptyLineSeparatorCheckTest.java#L305-L311 * `testJavadocCommentAfterPackageWithImports()` https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5444844c338dfe2b9a3543721af62cc40113ecee/src/test/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/EmptyLineSeparatorCheckTest.java#L184-L192 * `testPrePreviousLineIsEmpty()` https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5444844c338dfe2b9a3543721af62cc40113ecee/src/test/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/EmptyLineSeparatorCheckTest.java#L314-L322 --- ## Why changing these tests to use `verifyWithInlineConfigParser()` does not work Adding the config inside the `Input*.java` file and tweaking the `expect`ed variable will make each test pass. [Here is a commit that makes these changes.](https://github.com/stoyanK7/checkstyle/commit/684e19fa028d70e912e96fe31156fe20cc559178) ### Coverage issues **However**,  `mvn clean verify` shows that branch coverage is now at `0.99`: ![crash](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23459549/177387996-15d2c485-bff9-469c-856d-afe0ec43fb90.png)  Generating test coverage report with `mvn -e clean test -Dtest=EmptyLineSeparatorCheckTest jacoco:restore-instrumented-classes jacoco:report@default-report` shows that coverage issues occur on the following 2 lines: * https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5444844c338dfe2b9a3543721af62cc40113ecee/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/EmptyLineSeparatorCheck.java#L646 ![647](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23459549/177388025-f0163782-3130-47b9-90d7-310f75248264.png)  * https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5444844c338dfe2b9a3543721af62cc40113ecee/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/EmptyLineSeparatorCheck.java#L812 ![812](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23459549/177388042-e781e633-b65b-446d-a276-4b29100a8338.png)  --- After having added the configuration in the `Input*.java` files, the AST's being checked would move 11(or so) rows down and would no longer be on lines * `1`. Will go to line `13` https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5e2873f627630f304c3d30edde42192f967bd1c5/src/test/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/emptylineseparator/InputEmptyLineSeparatorJavadocCommentAfterPackage.java#L1 * `2`. Will go to line `13` https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5e2873f627630f304c3d30edde42192f967bd1c5/src/test/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/emptylineseparator/InputEmptyLineSeparatorPrePreviousLineEmptiness.java#L2 * `3`. Will go to line `14` https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/5e2873f627630f304c3d30edde42192f967bd1c5/src/test/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/whitespace/emptylineseparator/InputEmptyLineSeparatorPrePreviousLineIsEmpty.java#L3  which means `ast.getLineNo() > 1`  and `lineNo >= number(3)` will now always be `true`. The `false` branches are no longer covered.   ## The problem The problem is that you need those ASTs staying on those first lines(`1`,`2` and `3`) to cover the `false` branches but in order to utilize inline configs, the configs need to be placed in the beginning of the file and therefore push the code down away from those first lines.

column3: Group Shell Scripts by Activity and not CI
column4: Re-identified at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11028#discussion_r767165973 but discussed at other times. Making sure we have an issue.  It has become common that we have to rotate CIs when one becomes over bloated, one starts to have reliable issues, etc. all of which we have run into before.  We should group all our shell scripts by their activity instead of strictly putting it in the CI. For example, we should have script for regression, another for pitest (which we already do), etc...  Travis as one example still requires us to put commonds in shell. For the split we want, we should use a pattern similar to the below: ```` no-error-spring-cloud-gcp)   mvn -e --no-transfer-progress clean install -Pno-validations   ./.validation.sh no-error-spring-cloud-gcp ````  This way CI config and CI specific shell remove all CI specific commands, and under them there is group's shell script (validaiton.sh in this case) that try to be CI agnostic.

column3: Replace System.exit with Runtime.exit
column4: Prerequisite for #9146   Switching to Java11 breaks pitest-main report: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900805/148722335-3682b9e5-49b8-4353-b91a-059f2311866e.png) There is one "uncovered" line may be related to https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/181 The bytecode generated by JDK8 compiler almost the same as bytecode generated by JDK11 compiler. With one difference: JDK11 invokes `ExitHelper#exit` directly, JDK8 generates a helper method named `access$100`.  We need another way to test the `Main.main` method. One possibility is to replace `System#exit` with `Runtime#exit`. From the [docs](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/System.html#exit(int)): >  The call `System.exit(n)` is effectively equivalent to the call `Runtime.getRuntime().exit(n)`  It is possible to mock `Runtime#exit` method and use `Mockito#verify` method to check the exit code passed.

column3: Include CDG Accelerator Plugin to boost pitest performance
column4: Pitest takes a significant amount of time to execute in the CI, there are ways in which this time can be improved. Fast feedback form CI will be important in long run and will be super important for this summer's project.  The CDG Accelerator Plugin or the JUnit 5 Accelerator Plugin claims to improves mutation test performance by reducing the overhead in running tests that use a limited set of JUnit Jupiter features. Tests that use only these features will run more quickly, tests that use features outside this set will be executed as normal.  See https://docs.arcmutate.com/docs/accelerator.html#eligible-tests section for the eligible tests.  A license needs to be acquired in order to use the plugin, it is free for open-source projects. See https://www.arcmutate.com/pricing/ for more details.

column3: Issue #11140: solve PRMC_POSSIBLY_REDUNDANT_METHOD_CALLS
column4: Part of #11140   In fact, this is nano optimization with zero impact. But this forces us to add more variables to the code. This makes the code readable and easy to debug.  There is a false-positive for `Checker` and `TreeWalker`. See https://github.com/mebigfatguy/fb-contrib/issues/329 for the details.

column3: Issue #11140: solve OCP_OVERLY_CONCRETE_PARAMETER
column4: Part of #11140   [Description](http://fb-contrib.sourceforge.net/bugdescriptions.html#OCP_OVERLY_CONCRETE_PARAMETER)  > This method uses concrete classes for parameters when only methods defined in an implemented interface or superclass are used. Consider increasing the abstraction of the interface to make low impact changes easier to accomplish in the future.  In general, this makes sense. But sometimes it requires additional imports from foreign packages.  Code: ```java     private static void addLastSibling(DetailAstImpl self, DetailAstImpl sibling) { ```  Report: ``` [ERROR] Medium: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaAstVisitor.addLastSibling(DetailAstImpl, DetailAstImpl): 2nd parameter 'sibling' could be declared as com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.DetailAST instead  [com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.JavaAstVisitor] At JavaAstVisitor.java:[line 2145] OCP_OVERLY_CONCRETE_PARAMETER ```  Suggested code: ```java import com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.DetailAST; // New import required      private static void addLastSibling(DetailAstImpl self, DetailAST sibling) { ```  such cases are false positives and should be suppressed.

column3: Reuse Plain text release notes from releasenotes-builder in Github release page
column4: page https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/releases/tag/checkstyle-10.3 right now we post only link to release notes.  but we can use Plain text content of releasenotes builder to generate new post in Github format. Keep "Plan text" unchanged and create new template and "Github post":  We can add `#XXXX` at the begining of text lines so links will be active and easy to use. `#XXXXXX: title` we need to keep grouping of issue as it is now in Plan text release notes.   no links to issues for Notes section!!! Example plain text released notes generation https://cloud.drone.io/checkstyle/checkstyle/11388/4/2  Structure of new post:  ``` Checkstyle 10.4 - https://checkstyle.org/releasenotes.html#Release_10.4  Breaking compatibility:   #xxxx - Change ....  New features:   #xxxx - Support ....  Bug fixes:   #xxxx - Support qualified annotation names   #xxxx - Update google_checks.xml to have the SuppressionCommentFilter and SuppressWarningsHolder modules in the config by default (and by extension, SuppressWarningsFilter)   Notes:   Pitest: Kill all surviving mutations   update code base to have javadoc tag to explain noinspection tag content   doc: put example of enableExternalDtdLoad to xdoc   update doc for SuppressWarningsHolder   releasenotes script generated empty commit   Include CDG Accelerator Plugin to boost pitest performance   Enforce file size on Java inputs   Expand XPath IT Regression Testing   There are semantic problems in the Chinese error message of keyword `design.forExtension` .   prepare-settings.sh fails to create settings.xml   Use groovy version provided by `apt` in pitest.yml   Solve fb-contrib errors   tweet-releasenotes.sh does not check env variables   download of m2 cache from sourceforge.io is slow    infra: turns off create dependency reduced pom for shade plugin   Update Tests to use new 'verifyXxxxxx' method or 'execute' that use inlined config in Input files   Specify violation messages in input files.   pitest: increase mutation coverage for javadoc profile to 100%  ============================================== ```  This will make github release page be more readable.  We do update of this page at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/8c7e41abefa2a9e004b0dfd7c6eee9dc8a23027d/release.sh#L65   example of release notes page https://github.com/hcoles/pitest/releases/tag/1.9.0  It should be a script that takes Github token from file as it is done in release.sh and do update over existing release page. Eventually it will be executed from release.sh script as just another command.

Take a look at contribution to see how it is done there: https://github.com/checkstyle/contribution/blob/master/checkstyle-tester/codenarc.sh  _Originally posted by @nick-mancuso in https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/11731#issuecomment-1153228921_

column3: Enforce formatting of `// violation` and `// ok` comments
column4: Noticed in many PR's, it is difficult to make sure that all BDD and documentation related comments (`// ok` and `// violation`) adhere to consistent format. We can save time in PR reviews by adding `RegexpSingleline` modules to associated configs.   Usual convention:  ``` ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -R "\/\/ ok" | wc -l 4049 ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -R "\/\/ violation" | wc -l 74064  ```  We should forbid the following forms of comments:  ``` ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -iR "\/\/ok" | wc -l  341 ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -iR "\/\/violation" | wc -l 107 ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -R "\/\/ Violation" | wc -l 61 ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -R "\/\/ VIOLATION" | wc -l 1 ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -R "\/\/ OK" | wc -l 1563 ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -R "\/\/ bad" | wc -l 6 ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -R "\/\/bad" | wc -l 8 ➜  checkstyle git:(master) ✗ grep -R "\/\/ no violation" | wc -l 203  ```  While check input files are not a big deal (but should also be fixed and enforced), many of these are in documentation, where we should make sure to always be consistent.

column3: `checkstyle_checks.xml` should not allow single letter variable names in for loops
column4: Noticed at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11371#pullrequestreview-932821582:   Right now, there is 85 errors in `master` branch that are suppressed, We need help to remove all suppresions and update names of variables. Examples of updates: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/commit/2bf4bf71e2244e0c26d5f969cc2f384c170e6f41  Already DONE: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/c1c41d49ca6829df3c0dcf3e8ca980838c8ef0bf/config/checkstyle_checks.xml#L758-L761  Right now, we have `allowOneCharVarInForLoop` property set to `true`, which allows for single letter variable names. For readability, we should enforce the same naming conventions on for loop variables that we do on other local variables. Instead of `i`, let's use `index`.

column3: Forbid usage of Truth's `StandardSubjectBuilder#fail` method.
column4: Noticed at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11270#discussion_r803082439  Now that we have come to an agreement on `assertThrows`, we should enforce usage by adding a `MatchXPath` module to `checkstyle_checks.xml`:  ```  ➜   cat TestClass.java import org.junit.Test;  import static com.google.common.truth.Truth.assertWithMessage; import static org.junit.Assert.assertThrows;  public class TestClass {     @Test     public void testMethodBad() {         try {             int[] arr = new int[]{};             int x = arr[2];             assertWithMessage("IndexOutOfBoundsException expected").fail();         } catch (IndexOutOfBoundsException ex) {             assertWithMessage("Invalid error message")                     .that(ex.getMessage())                     .isEqualTo("Index 2 out of bounds for length 0");         }     }      @Test     public void testMethodGood() {          int[] arr = new int[]{};         final IndexOutOfBoundsException exception =                 assertThrows(IndexOutOfBoundsException.class,                         () -> {                             int i = arr[2];                         });          assertWithMessage("Invalid error message")                 .that(exception.getMessage())                 .isEqualTo("Index 2 out of bounds for length 0");      } }  ➜  cat  config.xml                                                                    ➜  java -jar checkstyle-9.3-all.jar -c config.xml TestClass.java  Starting audit... [ERROR] TestClass.java:12:30: Exceptions should be validated by JUnit's `Assert#assertThrows`. [MatchXpath] Audit done. Checkstyle ends with 1 errors.   ```  We will need to fix existing usages: ``` ➜  checkstyle git:(master) grep -R "assertWithMessage.*fail()" | wc -l 244  ```

column3: New check ChainedMethodCallWrap
column4: Noticed at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11081#discussion_r773266420   and https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11083/files#r773320264   It would be good to have an easy way to make sure that certain method calls are wrapped for readability. A good example from this repo is google truth assertions:   **How I would like check to work:**   config:  ```xml                                                                           ```  input:   ```java import static com.google.common.truth.Truth.assertWithMessage; import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;  public class TestClass {      @Test     void myTest() {         final String actual = "some string";         final String expected = "some string";         assertWithMessage("some message") // ok                 .that(actual)                 .isEqualTo(expected);          assertWithMessage("some message").that(actual).isEqualTo(expected); // violation, too many calls for single line chain         assertThat(actual).isEqualTo(expected); // ok by maxSingleLineCalls property         assertWithMessage("some message")                 .that(actual).isEqualTo(expected); // violation, chained method call should be wrapped }  ```  expected output:   ```bash  /var/tmp $ java $RUN_LOCALE -jar checkstyle-9.2-all.jar -c config.xml TestClass.java [ERROR] TestClass.java:14:8: Too many method calls on single line. [ChainedMethodCallWrap] [ERROR] TestClass.java:17:31: Chained method call should be wrapped. [ChainedMethodCallWrap]   ```  Note that check should have two messages.  **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.** The problem is that no check/ combination of check and suppression easily allows enforcing of line wrapping chained method calls.   **Describe the solution you'd like** I would like a new check that accepts a method name pattern, so that common long chains of method calls (in assertions, builders, stream operations) can be validated for readability purposes.  ---------------------------------  I would like this check to have the following properties (ignore above example, and only consider the given code snippets):  `maxSingleLineCalls` : the maximum number of calls for a single line method call chain. Once we begin wrapping calls, this property has no effect, and number of calls per line is enforced by `callsPerLine` property.  Config:  ```xml                                          ```  Example:  ```java assertThat(thing1).equals(thing2);// ok, by maxSingleLineCalls  assertWithMessage("message") // ok         .that(thing1)         .equals(thing2);  assertWithMessage("message").that(thing1) // ok, callsPerLine default is 2         .equals(thing2);  assertWithMessage("message").that(thing1).equals(thing2); // 2 violations, too many calls for single line chain  ```  `callsPerLine`: this property sets the maximum number of method calls allowed on any given line of chained method calls once we begin line wrapping calls.   Config:   ```xml                                                     ```  Example:   ```java assertWithMessage("message") // ok         .that(thing1)         .equals(thing2);  assertWithMessage("message").that(thing1) // violation, chained method call should be wrapped         .equals(thing2);  assertWithMessage("message").that(thing1).equals(thing2); // 2 violations, too many calls for single line chain  ```  `identifierPattern` : this property would be used to specify regex by user of methods to check. User can specify any form of method invocation identifier, such as:  ```  . . ```  Check logic would work like this:  Generate complete method invocation identifier. This should be checked against given regex.  ```java public class Test {     void m() {         ClassUtil.get(requiredArguments) // yields "ClassUtil.get"                 .setDate(date)                 .setTitle(title);          get(requiredArguments) // yields "get"                 .setDate(date)                 .setTitle(title);     } }  ```  In either case, we generate identifier from first child of initial method call:  ``` ... METHOD_CALL -> ( [4:21]  |--DOT -> . [4:17]  |   |--IDENT -> ClassUtil [4:8]  |   `--IDENT -> get [4:18]  |--ELIST -> ELIST [4:22]  |   `--EXPR -> EXPR [4:22]  |       `--IDENT -> requiredArguments [4:22]  `--RPAREN -> ) [4:39] ... METHOD_CALL -> ( [8:11]  |--IDENT -> get [8:8]  |--ELIST -> ELIST [8:12]  |   `--EXPR -> EXPR [8:12]  |       `--IDENT -> requiredArguments [8:12]  `--RPAREN -> ) [8:29] ... ```   Config:  ```xml                      // covers any method from ClassUtil.java                                ```  Example:  ```java ClassUtil.get(requiredArguments) // ok         .setDate(date)         .setTitle(title);  ClassUtil.get(requiredArguments).setDate(date) // ok, by callsPerLine = 2         .setTitle(title);   ClassUtil.get(requiredArguments).setDate(date)         .setTitle(title).setTime(time) // ok, by callsPerLine = 2         .setOtherParameter(other);  ClassUtil.get(requiredArguments).setDate(date)         .setTitle(title).setTime(time).setOtherParameter(other) // violation, chained method call should be wrapped         .setSomeOtherParameter(someOther);  ClassUtil.get(requiredArguments).setDate(date)         .setTitle(title).setTime(time).setParameter(thing).setOtherParameter(other) // 2 violations, chained method call should be wrapped         .setSomeOtherParameter(someOther);  ClassUtil.get(requiredArguments).setDate(date).setTitle(title); // violation, too many calls for single line chain  get(requiredArguments) // ok         .setDate(date)         .setTitle(title)  ```    This initial implementation would not check imports in any way.

column3: Check no closed issue references workflow is not triggered on pull requests
column4: Noticed at - https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11437#issuecomment-1073116935 The action doesn't run on pull requests. Also, it doesn't specify the location where the issue is mentioned. ``` Following issues are mentioned in code to do something after they are closed: https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/10737 ``` The location along with the issue will be helpful.  ----  What the related PR should do-  1. **Improved reporting:-** A clickable link is now given to the user which redirects it to the line where the closed issue is referenced.  2. **Runs on a PR:-** The job now runs on a PR too. 3. **Issues linked to PR are mentioned:-** If the developer has linked some issue to the PR and that issue is referenced somewhere in the code then a violation will be given out to user. Rationale behind this is that if you [link](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) an issue to a PR then when that PR is merged, then that issue would be automatically closed, linking issue is different than just mentioning it.

column3: Mutations created by INLINE_CONSTS mutator are hard to understand
column4: Noticed at #11873   While adding the `ALL` mutator group, surviving mutations created by the `INLINE_CONSTS` mutator became hard to debug.  ```java private void validateDefaultJavadocTokens() {     if (getRequiredJavadocTokens().length != 0) {         final int[] defaultJavadocTokens = getDefaultJavadocTokens();         Arrays.sort(defaultJavadocTokens);         for (final int javadocToken : getRequiredJavadocTokens()) {             if (Arrays.binarySearch(defaultJavadocTokens, javadocToken) < 0) {                 final String message = String.format(Locale.ROOT,                                                      "Javadoc Token \"%s\" from required javadoc "                                                          + "tokens was not found in default "                                                          + "javadoc tokens list in check %s",                                                      javadocToken, getClass().getName());                 throw new IllegalStateException(message);             }         }     } } ``` Surviving Mutation was on line- ```java final String message = String.format(Locale.ROOT, ``` ``` Substituted 2 with 3 → SURVIVED ``` The explanation given by @rnveach at https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/pull/11873#discussion_r920652226:  > Please remember, pitest is a bytecode manipulator. It doesn't read or understand the source code. If you really want to understand what pitest is doing, you need to look at the bytecode. >  > > I do not understand what is 2 and what is 3 in such code. >  > The source, > ```` >                     final String message = String.format(Locale.ROOT, >                             "Javadoc Token \"%s\" from required javadoc " >                                 + "tokens was not found in default " >                                 + "javadoc tokens list in check %s", >                             javadocToken, getClass().getName()); > ```` >  > converts to: >  > > javap -c -l '.\AbstractJavadocCheck.class' >  > ```` >       49: getstatic     #32                 // Field java/util/Locale.ROOT:Ljava/util/Locale; >       52: ldc           #42                 // String Javadoc Token \"%s\" from required javadoc tokens was not found in default javadoc tokens list in check %s >       54: iconst_2 >       55: anewarray     #34                 // class java/lang/Object >       58: dup >       59: iconst_0 >       60: iload         5 >       62: invokestatic  #14                 // Method java/lang/Integer.valueOf:(I)Ljava/lang/Integer; >       65: aastore >       66: dup >       67: iconst_1 >       68: aload_0 >       69: invokevirtual #36                 // Method java/lang/Object.getClass:()Ljava/lang/Class; >       72: invokevirtual #37                 // Method java/lang/Class.getName:()Ljava/lang/String; >       75: aastore >       76: invokestatic  #38                 // Method java/lang/String.format:(Ljava/util/Locale;Ljava/lang/String;[Ljava/lang/Object;)Ljava/lang/String; >       79: astore        6 > ```` >  > I'll avoid going too far, but basically pitest is manipulating the iconst_2 ( https://github.com/hcoles/pitest/blob/master/pitest/src/main/java/org/pitest/mutationtest/engine/gregor/mutators/InlineConstantMutator.java#L204 ) connected to the following lines: > ```` >       54: iconst_2 >       55: anewarray     #34                 // class java/lang/Object > ```` >  > So what is this code doing and how did it come from the source? >  > Basically, `String.format` parameters are `format(Locale l, String format, Object... args)` and this all comes down to how `Object...` is handled in the bytecode when calling this method. >  > The source passes each part of the `args` as separate strings, but the method doesn't accept separate strings. It accepts only an array. What Java does for the developers to make coding easier is it sees and makes this simple conversion for you. >  > To make this conversion it actually instantiates an Object array for you and puts the arguments you are passing into the array and passes that to the method. In this case we are passing **2** strings to the `args`. So basically your simple `   javadocToken, getClass().getName()` in the source actually becomes `new Object[] {javadocToken, getClass().getName()}` or basically: > ```` > final Object[] temp = new Object[2]; > temp[0] = javadocToken; > temp[1] = getClass().getName(); > ```` >  > You all can start to see where the 2 comes into play here. It is the number of arguments being passed specifically to the `Object...`. >  > 3 is just the new value pitest is replacing 2 with to look and find some failure. IE: `new Object[2]` ==> `new Object[3]`. >  > If you actually embed the bytecode representation in the source and place it on an isolated line and run pitest, you will see the surviving mutant is only on this line and the rest of the code passes.

column3: Improve Japanese message translation
column4: Messages in `messages_ja.properties` (especially ones added after version 8.24) contain some mistranslated messages.  For example, in `src/main/resources/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/imports/messages_ja.properties`, the message : ``` import.illegal=違法輸入 - {0}。 ``` means the illegal imports in the context of international trades. It should be: ``` import.illegal=インポートが不正です - {0}。 ```
